parent_formation: X Corps, British Eighth Army (until 13 May); then preparing for Operation Husky (Sicily)

commander.name: Major-General George Erskine
commander.previous_service: Commanded 43rd (Wessex) Infantry Division. Appointed to 7th Armoured Division when Harding wounded December 1942.
commander.notes: Led division through final Tunisia battles: Wadi Akarit (6-7 April 1943), final offensive to Tunis (April-May), and Axis surrender (13 May 1943). Post-victory: reorganization, rest, and preparation for Sicily invasion (Operation Husky, July 1943).

command.headquarters_location: Tunisia (April-May: mobile operations toward Tunis; May-June: rest areas near Sousse and Sfax preparing for Sicily)

Sherman M4.notes: 75mm gun. Main battle tank. Numbers increased post-Tunisia. Excellent reliability (98% operational after maintenance standdown).

Sherman M4A2.notes: Diesel variant. Increased allocation post-Tunisia for Sicily operations. Better range than gasoline Shermans.

Crusader III.notes: 6-pounder gun. Being phased out. Numbers reduced from 32 (Q1) to 20 as Shermans replace them. May not deploy to Sicily.

Stuart M3 'Honey'.notes: 37mm gun. Reconnaissance squadrons. Proven reliable in Tunisia Campaign.

Stuart M5.notes: Improved Stuart with twin Cadillac engines. Numbers increasing as M3 attrition replaced.

Marmon-Herrington Mk III.role: South African pattern, reconnaissance. Some transferred/losses in final Tunisia battles.

Universal Carrier.role: Infantry support, reconnaissance, mortar carrier. Some losses in Tunisia finale.

Water bowser.role: Water supply (further reduced post-Tunisia, Sicily prep)

Ordnance QF 25-pounder Mk II.notes: Two field regiments (3rd RHA and 5th RHA), 24 guns each. Fired extensive barrages during final Tunisia offensive. Post-victory: maintenance, ammunition restocking.

Ordnance QF 6-pounder (57mm).notes: Anti-tank regiment now entirely 6-pounders. Last 2-pounders transferred out. Effective against all German armour except Tiger frontal armor at range.

Bofors 40mm.notes: Light AA battery for divisional air defense. Limited Luftwaffe activity post-Tunisia.

supply_logistics.supply_status: Excellent. Tunisia secured 13 May 1943. Division in rest and refit areas (Sousse, Sfax region) with direct access to ports. Supply lines minimal (50-100km). Post-victory reorganization: vehicle maintenance, tank overhaul, ammunition restocking, personnel replacements. Preparing for Operation Husky (Sicily) with intensive training and equipment upgrades. North African supply infrastructure now fully operational with Bizerte, Tunis, Sousse, and Sfax ports available.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Tunisia coastal region - Mediterranean coast, agricultural plains, hills (Sousse-Sfax rest areas)

subordinate_units.composition: 1st Royal Tank Regiment (RTR), 5th RTR, 4th County of London Yeomanry (CLY/Sharpshooters), 1st Rifle Brigade (Motor Battalion)
subordinate_units.notes: Elite armoured brigade. Fought through Tunisia finale. Post-13 May: rest, maintenance, retraining for Sicily. Sherman allocation increased, Crusaders reduced. Preparing for amphibious operations (new doctrine).

subordinate_units.composition: 1/5th Battalion Queen's Royal Regiment, 1/6th Battalion Queen's Royal Regiment, 1/7th Battalion Queen's Royal Regiment
subordinate_units.notes: Motor infantry brigade. Casualties replaced post-Tunisia. Training for Sicily invasion with emphasis on beach operations and rapid exploitation inland.

subordinate_units.composition: Royal Scots Greys, 4th Hussars (Queen's Own), 8th Hussars (King's Royal Irish), 2nd Derbyshire Yeomanry (reconnaissance)
subordinate_units.notes: Reconnaissance brigade. Stuart light tanks and armoured cars. Post-Tunisia maintenance and replacement of worn vehicles. Preparing for Sicily reconnaissance role.
Self-propelled mobile artillery. Extensive barrel wear from Tunisia Campaign - barrels replaced/refurbished. Ammunition stocks replenished.
Second field artillery regiment. Same maintenance cycle as 3rd RHA. Preparing for Sicily fire support operations.

subordinate_units.composition: Multiple anti-tank batteries, now entirely 6-pounder equipped
subordinate_units.notes: All 2-pounders replaced with 6-pounders. Standardized equipment improves logistics. No German armour threat post-Tunisia, focusing on training.
Light AA defense. Limited air threat post-Tunisia. Preparing for Sicily where Luftwaffe expected more active.

subordinate_units.composition: Communications squadrons, wireless sections, line sections
subordinate_units.notes: Divisional communications network. Equipment maintenance post-campaign. New wireless procedures for Sicily.

subordinate_units.composition: Field squadrons, workshop sections, bridging sections
subordinate_units.notes: Mine clearance expertise from Tunisia. Preparing for Sicily beach obstacles, demolitions, and rapid bridge construction.

subordinate_units.composition: Transport companies, supply columns, petrol company, water company
subordinate_units.notes: Royal Army Service Corps. Post-Tunisia: vehicle overhaul, spare parts restocking. Preparing for Sicily amphibious logistics (new challenge).

tactical_doctrine.role: Elite mobile armoured division. Primary role Q2 1943: Complete Tunisia Campaign (April-13 May), then rest/refit/retrain for Operation Husky (Sicily invasion, July 1943). Transition from desert warfare to Mediterranean amphibious operations.
special_capabilities: Veteran North Africa combat experience (43 months continuous combat by June 1943)
Combined arms mastery (armour, infantry, artillery coordination)
Anti-German tactics (extensive Afrika Korps combat experience)
High morale from Tunisia victory (13 May 1943)
tactical_innovations: Mixed tank squadrons (Sherman heavy + Stuart light)
Motor infantry integration with armoured brigades
Radio net coordination for dispersed operations
NEW: Amphibious operations training for Sicily (beach landings, rapid inland exploitation)
known_issues: Transition from desert to Mediterranean terrain (more restrictive)
Amphibious operations inexperience (never conducted beach landing)
Sherman vulnerability to German 88mm and Pak 40 remains
Crusader III being phased out (supply complexity during transition)
Vehicle wear from 43 months continuous operations (extensive maintenance required)
Sicily terrain more mountainous than Tunisia (mobility restrictions)
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Division retains desert warfare expertise but adapting to new environment. Post-Tunisia training emphasizes: amphibious operations coordination, Mediterranean terrain (mountains, hills, urban areas), inter-service coordination with Royal Navy, close air support with RAF, and rapid exploitation from beachheads. Desert skills (navigation, supply discipline, mobile warfare) remain foundation.

validation.notes: Data compiled from British armoured division establishment tables Q2 1943 and Tunisia Campaign historical records. Key Q2 events: Battle of Wadi Akarit (6-7 April), final Tunisia offensive, Axis surrender (13 May), rest/refit/retrain May-June for Sicily. Personnel strength reduced slightly to 14,650 (from 14,920) reflecting battle casualties April-May not yet fully replaced. Tank strength reduced to 172 (from 178) but Sherman allocation increased to 100 (from 92) as Crusader IIIs phased out to 20 (from 32). Light tanks reduced to 52 (from 54). Post-13 May: Division in rest areas near Sousse/Sfax with excellent supply access. Operational rate improved to 97% (from 91%) after maintenance standdown. Supply reserves dramatically increased: fuel 14 days (from 7.5), ammunition 21 days (from 12) with no active operations. Commander Erskine continued. Division preparing for Operation Husky (Sicily invasion July 1943) - first amphibious operation, requiring new training and doctrine. Morale peak at 10/10 from Tunisia victory.
